ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of new vocabulary and sentence structures. I also learned a lot about specific controversial topics important in Chinese culture and history, such as tiger moms, the AIDs problem in China, NGOs in China, China-America relations, abortion, and family expectations. Learning how to talk about these things in Chinese was very useful and helped me begin to learn how to speak precisely in another language, which is necessary when talking about controversial issues that some people might be offended by.

I developed greater Chinese language skills, especially communicating opinions on complex social issues. Additionally, this class offers an introduction to hand writing in Chinese characters in preparation for higher level requirements.
Chinese, how to talk about government, policies, the environment, Chinese culture, etc.
Discussions on current issues and politics in China and comparing them to other countries, advanced grammar and vocabulary

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The textbook was engaging and well organized, and the structure of interleaving teaching and discussion/speaking practice was well executed. I wish that I could have received my tests with specific corrections instead of just a grade.

STRENGTHS: well-structured, engaging topics, lots of associated events to develop Chinese skills, small class sizes that help learning, final project instead of cumulative exam

WEAKNESSES: the two exams covered more content and introduced new elements that weren't in L3-4 tests like a large handwriting requirement. They weren't necessarily excessively difficult, but it felt like we weren't really prepared in class for the jump in difficulty.
Great Course! My only suggestion would be to give a few more days of studying the unit before having us submit the read-aloud recording of the text.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I love the Chinese department at Yale, and this class was probably my favorite  I have taken so far.

Yes, if you are interested in progressing in Chinese. If it is not very important to you/your major, then it may be difficult to stay motivated with the almost nightly workload and constant intellectual challenge. It is definitely not a light fifth class even though it is no longer 1.5 credits/everyday like L3-4. However, the professors are very knowledgeable and care about their student's success. It is one of the best and most organized language departments at Yale.
Yes! It is a lot of work, but definitely nice not to have to go eery day as in CHNS 110-140.
If you want to become proficient in mandarin Chinese this course is a must.
